examples: He's extremely irritable - he flies off the handle at the slightest thing.
They are irritable with friends.
They are irritable with their parents.
Concentrating on things is hard, you can get irritable.
Your muscles begin to ache, you grow irritable, and you lose your appetite.
words.defineEn: easily annoyed or made angry; displaying anger
words.defineVi: dễ dàng khó chịu hoặc tức giận; thể hiện sự tức giận

examples: And nothing was so irritating as the confident way he used archaic idiom.
Things irritate you?
These stabby crystals, and other plant proteins on them, can severely irritate the delicate tissue in a mouth.
Everything irritates me.
It all irritates you.
words.defineEn: cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations
words.defineVi: gây bức xúc trong; làm phiền, đặc biệt là bởi những kích thích nhỏ

examples: Beau: I am very active.
So, Beau, tell us about yourself.
So, I definitely think Beau.
Beau: Connor, you're a delightful young man.
Beau had served in Iraq.
words.defineEn: a man who is the lover of a man or woman
words.defineVi: một người đàn ông là người yêu của một người đàn ông hay phụ nữ

words.defineEn: marked by utter benignity; resembling or befitting an angel or saint
words.defineVi: được đánh dấu bởi sự lành tính hoàn toàn; giống hoặc phù hợp với một thiên thần hoặc thánh

words.defineEn: declare (a dead person) to be blessed; the first step of achieving sainthood
words.defineVi: tuyên bố (một người chết) được ban phước; bước đầu tiên để đạt được sự thánh thiện

words.defineEn: one of the eight sayings of Jesus at the beginning of the Sermon on the Mount; in Latin each saying begins with `beatus' (blessed)
words.defineVi: một trong tám câu nói của Chúa Giêsu ở đầu Bài giảng trên núi; trong tiếng Latinh, mỗi câu nói bắt đầu bằng 'beatus' (được ban phước)

examples: James's acting career had been stagnant, but landing a lead role in a popular TV series provided him with a new lease on life.
And that sheet isn’t stagnant.
But the rise of e-commerce shipping boxes has provided a boost to the stagnant cardboard box market.
Donald Trump is the consequence of years of stagnant wages and an overwhelming dominance of corporations and Wall Street and wealthy people in our politics.
Fantasy was a market that was stagnant.
At the same time, wages have been stagnating.
While in the 1980s 218 new nuclear power reactors went live, their number and nuclear’s global share of electricity production has stagnated since the end of the ’80s.
At that time, inflation soared while output stagnated.
But there's a huge number whichhave really stagnated.
Some argue that Luxottica's disproportionate size and power stifles competition, causing the whole industry to stagnate.
words.defineEn: be idle; exist in a changeless situation
words.defineVi: nhàn rỗi; tồn tại trong một tình huống không thay đổi

examples: The years of stagnation did a lot of harm to the younger generation.
So you're really having near stagnation in Europe.
And if you've got a pressure gauge on the back of that hole, you can measure what's called the stagnation pressure.
The more air that comes into that front port, the higher the stagnation pressure.
This stage, Stage 7, highlights our tendency toward either generativity or stagnation.
words.defineEn: a state of inactivity (in business or art etc)
words.defineVi: trạng thái không hoạt động (trong kinh doanh hoặc nghệ thuật, v.v.)

examples: But users were opting in and the campaign's tech savvy was lauded.
Jimmy Carter is the rare U.S. president who is most lauded for his work after the Oval Office.
This painting of exactly what is seen before you may seem pretty basic now, but then it was wildly different than the static, composed history pictures lauded by the establishment.

And so I think what happened is we were all so excited about the rise of the amateur that we missed the bigger societal implications, which is that when we laud amateurism in fun ways, like you know, singing and playing the ukulele, we also begin to reward the amateur in the realm of politics and leadership.
words.defineVi: ca ngợi, tôn vinh, hoặc tôn vinh

words.defineEn: (of an idea, intention, or act) deserving of admiration and praise, regardless of success
words.defineVi: (về một ý tưởng, ý định hoặc hành động) xứng đáng được ngưỡng mộ và khen ngợi, bất kể thành công
đầy hoặc đưa ra lời khen ngợi

examples: Ground contact was maintained with the ascent stage until its batteries were depleted, some 12 hours later.
There's something called socially facilitated ascent.
There's nothing left to do now and our oxygen is running out, so we begin our ascent.
The ascent is so rapid, that even McDonald's and Popeye's are taking note.
For one reason or another, they either couldn’t or didn’t control their ascent.
words.defineEn: the act or process of moving upwards
words.defineVi: hành động hoặc quá trình di chuyển lên trên

examples: And Dimetrodon was among a group of ascendant animals that would turn out to have a distinct advantage over the temnospondyls, as the climate began to change.
From that point on, he's a misfit in the party, and clear to everyone watching and involved that he no longer speaks for sort of the ascendant Republican base.

Well, the whole idea of a European Renaissance presupposes that Europe was like an island unto itself that was briefly enlightened when the Greeks were ascendant and then lost its way and then rediscovered its former European glory.
words.defineVi: có xu hướng hoặc hướng lên trên

examples: The international banking system is an enigma.
Chewing gum itself is an enigma.
But in 1989, this lone defiancewas an enigma, and the world's press wanteda name for the hero.
The great enigma of the face: do you draw it?
He's a bit of an enigma.
words.defineEn: the quality of being very challenging to explain or understand
words.defineVi: chất lượng rất khó giải thích hoặc hiểu

examples: No, it's very enigmatic.
In her enigmatic way, she represents the birth of a modern perspective on economics, politics, and love.
And when he started working at a mental hospital in eastern Switzerland, he began designing a series of puzzling images to gain new insight into this enigmatic process.
Beginning in June 1941, three million German soldiers and others from conquered territories rolled toward the USSR, with the enigmatic Stalin disappearing from view for the first days of the attack.
For one thing, equivalent performance on a task can obscure really important differences.
Always obscured.
People's faces across the country are obscured by masks.
Along comes this obscure Arkansas governor.
Just like on a hazy day, that dust could be obscuring our view of the star.
words.defineVi: làm cho ít nhìn thấy hơn hoặc không rõ ràng

words.defineEn: the quality of being unclear or abstruse and hard to understand
words.defineVi: chất lượng không rõ ràng hoặc trừu tượng và khó hiểu
